history.content:
You should be fine taking 126 or 127, as long as you are willing to grind.

Both 126 and 127 are extremely useful, so as far as deciding between them utility-wise you can't really go wrong.

The more relevant parts of CS70 for 126 are the latter parts, which you seemed to do better on.

126 is a more organized class, and has 2-3 weeks of CS70 probability review at the beginning as a refresher.

127 has slightly less hand-holding imo, but as long as you really like linear algebra or are pretty independent/willing to put in time, you should be fine.

I would recommend taking the class whose material you find more interesting.

Although it might seem like there is no point if your classmates are people who think 70/"advanced" math is trivial, you should not underestimate the benefit of taking such classes. They will definitely make you stronger.

So I'm an LS CS senior graduating a semester late so I have a little time to take some more classes that I think are worthwhile. From what I've heard, EE126 and EE127 are extremely useful classes in many ways. I would like to get a masters, so I feel like this is echoed even more so in my case (though I would like to get a masters focusing in something not necessarily ML related: networking, security, etc).

For relevant classes, I will have taken all CS lower divs, H54 and 53, CS70 and CS170 and CS188 by the time I take one of these courses. The only thing that concerns me is that the material for EE126 in particular looks inaccessible to someone who wasn't a literal god in the probability section of CS70/CS188. I received a B in CS70 with a breakdown of -1SD on MT1 -0.4 on MT2 and +1.2 on final. I'm willing to grind for my classes, but will I just be drowning with my peers who think 70/"advanced" math is trivial? With my background, what would you recommend?
history.subject: Can I take EE126 or EE127
